xml:
OFLOXACIN

List of individual interactants: Ofloxacin

96086002 Quinolones QUINOLONES Indications and dose

Local treatment of infections

To the eye

  • Child 1–17 years

    Apply every 2–4 hours for the first 2 days, then reduced to 4 times a day for maximum 10 days treatment.

  • Adult

    Apply every 2–4 hours for the first 2 days, then reduced to 4 times a day for maximum 10 days treatment.

Urinary-tract infections

By mouth

  • Adult

    200–400 mg daily, preferably taken in the morning; increased if necessary to 400 mg twice daily, in upper urinary tract infections.

Complicated urinary-tract infection

By intravenous infusion

  • Adult

    200 mg dailyIncreased to 400 mg twice daily, for severe or complicated infections, to be given over at least 30 minutes for each 200 mg.

Acute or chronic prostatitis

By mouth

  • Adult

    200 mg twice daily for 28 days.

Lower respiratory-tract infections

By mouth

  • Adult

    400 mg daily, dose preferably taken in the morning, then increased if necessary to 400 mg twice daily.

By intravenous infusion

  • Adult

    200 mg twice daily. increased to 400 mg twice daily, for severe or complicated infections. To be given over at least 30 minutes for each 200 mg.

Skin and soft-tissue infections

By mouth

  • Adult

    400 mg twice daily.

By intravenous infusion

  • Adult

    400 mg twice daily, to be given over at least 30 minutes for each 200 mg.

Uncomplicated gonorrhoea

By mouth

  • Adult

    400 mg once daily as a single dose.

Uncomplicated genital chlamydial infection

Non-gonococcal urethritis

By mouth

  • Adult

    400 mg daily for 7 days, dose may be taken as a single daily dose or in divided doses.

Pelvic inflammatory disease

By mouth

  • Adult

    400 mg twice daily for 14 days.

Septicaemia

By intravenous infusion

  • Adult

    200 mg twice daily. increased to 400 mg twice daily, for severe or complicated infections. To be given over at least 30 minutes for each 200 mg.

 Cautions

When used by eye

corneal ulcer (risk of corneal perforation); epithelial defect (risk of corneal perforation)

With intravenous use

acute myocardial infarction (risk factor for QT interval prolongation) (in adults); bradycardia (risk factor for QT interval prolongation) (in adults); congenital long QT syndrome (risk factor for QT interval prolongation) (in adults); electrolyte disturbances (risk factor for QT interval prolongation) (in adults); heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (risk factor for QT interval prolongation) (in adults); history of psychiatric illness (in adults); history of symptomatic arrhythmias (risk factor for QT interval prolongation) (in adults)

With oral use

acute myocardial infarction (risk factor for QT interval prolongation) (in adults); bradycardia (risk factor for QT interval prolongation) (in adults); congenital long QT syndrome (risk factor for QT interval prolongation) (in adults); electrolyte disturbances (risk factor for QT interval prolongation) (in adults); heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (risk factor for QT interval prolongation) (in adults); history of psychiatric illness (in adults); history of symptomatic arrhythmias (risk factor for QT interval prolongation) (in adults)
Interactions

With intravenous use or oral use in adults

Caution if concomitant use with other drugs known to prolong the QT interval.
Side-effects

Common or very common

When used by eye

eye irritation (in adults); ocular discomfort

With intravenous use

cough (in adults); eye irritation (in adults); nasopharyngitis (in adults)

With oral use

cough (in adults); eye irritation (in adults); nasopharyngitis (in adults)

Rare

With intravenous use

abnormal dreams (in adults); arrhythmias (in adults); bronchospasm (in adults); dyspnoea (in adults); hot flushes (in adults); hyperhidrosis (in adults)

With oral use

abnormal dreams (in adults); arrhythmias (in adults); bronchospasm (in adults); dyspnoea (in adults); hot flushes (in adults); hyperhidrosis (in adults)

Very rare

With intravenous use

extrapyramidal symptoms (in adults); neuropathy (in adults); tinnitus (in adults)

With oral use

extrapyramidal symptoms (in adults); neuropathy (in adults); tinnitus (in adults)

Frequency not known

When used by eye

dry eyes; facial oedema; increased lacrimation; keratitis; ocular hyperaemia; ocular oedema; photophobia; visual disturbances

With injectable use

myopathy (in adults)

With intravenous use

changes in blood sugar (in adults); hypotension (in adults); local reactions (in adults); pneumonitis (in adults); rhabdomyolysis (in adults); thrombophlebitis (in adults)

With oral use

changes in blood sugar (in adults); myopathy (in adults); pneumonitis (in adults); rhabdomyolysis (in adults)
Pregnancy

When used by eye

Manufacturer advises use only if benefit outweighs risk (systemic quinolones have caused arthropathy in animal studies).
Breast feeding

With intravenous use or oral use in adults

Amount probably too small to be harmful but manufacturer advises avoid.

When used by eye

Manufacturer advises avoid.
Hepatic impairment

With intravenous use or oral use in adults

Use with caution; elimination may be reduced in severe impairment.
Renal impairment

With intravenous use or oral use in adults

Usual initial dose, then use half normal dose if eGFR 20–50 mL/minute/1.73 m2; 100 mg every 24 hours if eGFR less than 20 mL/ minute/1.73 m2

Patient and carer advice
Driving and skilled tasks

With intravenous use or oral use in adults

May affect performance of skilled tasks (e.g. driving); effects enhanced by alcohol.
Medicinal forms

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral suspension, oral solution

 Drugs Tablet Solution for infusion Eye drops Drug classifications Urinary-tract infections Quinolones Leprosy Genital system infections, bacterial Eye, infections of Ear Ofloxacin QUINOLONES Drugs Tablet Solution for infusion Eye drops
